summary: On June 28, 2016, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment against a defendant who was convicted of securities fraud in connection with the sale of a residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS).  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in New York, alleges that Michael J. Litvak, a former bond trader at Jefferies & Company, falsely claimed that he was acting as an agent when, in fact, he was not acting as a principal in the RMBS transactions.  The complaint further alleges that, as a matter of law, the defendant had no agency relationship with the broker-dealer in which he sold the bond, and that he had no reasonable expectation of purchasing the bond at the price at which he would sell the bond.  In fact, as alleged in the complaint, the defendants' misstatements were not material to a reasonable investor because they were not relevant to the intrinsic value of the bond and the amount of money lost was not significant to the reasonable investor.    The court also ruled that the defendants were not liable for the loss of investor funds.  According to the SEC's Complaint:   In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New York today announced criminal charges against Litovak.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC Complaint, Litvinak consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay disgorgement of $73,018.53 plus prejudgment interest of $1,038.95, a civil penalty of $10,000, and a $50,000 officer and director bar.  Litvinac also agreed to be permanently enjoined from associating with any broker dealer, dealer, investment adviser, municipal securities dealer, municipal bond dealer, or nationally recognized statistical rating organization, and to be barred from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities.  He also agreed not to participate in the offering of any security in violation of the securities registration provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a)(1) and (3) of The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 17a-3 thereunder and to pay a $75,000 civil penalty.
